com.ibm.team.repository.client.util

Class ThreadCheck

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ibm.team.repository.client.util.ThreadCheck

  • public final class ThreadCheck
extends java.lang.Object
    Protection against accidentally invoking long-running operations from threads that must remain responsive.

    Usage: Call prohibitLongOps()from a UI thread (once is sufficient) to indicate that the thread must remain responsive. In code that does something long-running (e.g., read a file, access a network connection, or perform a computation longer than about 100ms), call checkLongOpsAllowed()to catch cases where the code has been invoked incorrectly on a time-critical thread.

    Since:
    0.5

    • Method Detail

      • longOpsProhibited

        public static boolean longOpsProhibited()
        Returns whether it is illegal to call a long-running operation (ones tagged &at;LongOp) from the calling thread. Initially false.
        Returns:
        true if long-running operations are prohibited, and false if long-running operations are allowed

      • checkLongOpsAllowed

        public static void checkLongOpsAllowed()
                                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        If the invoking thread is prohibited from performing long-running operations and disallow.server.ops.on.ui.thread system property is set to true, throws an exception, otherwise just logs the error.

        Call this method from inside the implementation of a long-running operation to help callers to not call this method when in a thread that must remain responsive. It is safe to call this method from anywhere; it will only fail if some party has deliberately marked the thread as needing to remain responsive, via a call to prohibitLongOps().

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the invoking thread is prohibited from performing long-running operations
        See Also:
        longOpsProhibited(), prohibitLongOps()

      • prohibitLongOps

        public static void prohibitLongOps()
        Declares that it is illegal to call a long-running operation (ones tagged &at;ServerOp) from the calling thread. Ignored if this method has already been called on this thread.

        This operation should be called on the thread(s) used by the UI. Doing so will ensure that any attempt to perform a long-running operation on that thread will fail immediately. This is to assist with best practices for keeping UIs responsive.

        Be careful which thread you call this method on. Once invoked, the thread cannot be used to call any long-running operations, and there is no way to unset this. In general, you should only be calling this method only in the UI thread (be wary of calling this method in a unit test setting where you might have no control over what other tests are running in the same thread).

      • runProhibitingLongOps

        public static void runProhibitingLongOps(java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        Runs the given runnable prohibiting long-running operations. After the runnable returns from running, the state of the current thread with respect to prohibiting long-running operations is restored to what it was before this call was made.
        Parameters:
        runnable - the runnable to run while long-running operations are prohibited; must not be null
        See Also:
        prohibitLongOps()

      • throwExceptionOnLongOp

        public static void throwExceptionOnLongOp(boolean value)
        Specifies what to do if a thread calls a long running operation after calling prohibitLongOps().
        Parameters:
        value - if true, then an exception is thrown for any thread that tries to call a long running operation after calling prohibitLongOps(). Otherwise the exception is only logged.
